title: Is USB C compatible with USB? - Quora

A typical question about the USB Type C Cable focuses on the relation between the Type C and the USB standard. Frankly speaking, there is no explicit relationship, since they are barely discussed under the same concept. Type C is basically an exterior connector for USB, while the USB standard is simply the standard for connector that distinguishes the different data delivering speeds. On April this year, the USB-IF organization just issued a brand new standard USB 3.2, which makes the super speed of 20Gbs possible. More importantly, this newly implemented standard is announced to be only adapted to Type C connector, highlighting the outstanding advantage of USB Type C Cable. At this level, the DP To HDMI DisplayPort Cable and the USB A-C Cable are presumed to lead a future fashion in the market in upcoming years. USB-C is USB, it's right there in the name. Type-C ports are just another option for terminating a USB cable. We have three (3) of them now; type-A, type-B and now type-C. Type-A is the one everyone is familiar with and is found on devices as an “output only” or “host” port. Type-B can come in a few size variants and until OTA was a thing was designed for use as an “input only” or “client" port. Type-C ports on the other hand are installed on devices that negotiate between each other which device will fulfill the “host” role and which the “client” role, this allows for bidirectional cables meaning you can put a type-C port on both ends and the devices themselves will decide if they are each sending or receiving power for example. The following chart displays the different options for USB cable termination and what each port is referred to:  Notice how the 3.1 port has a blue bit inside, that usually denotes that the cable is a USB 3.0 or 3.1 cable but in reality can be any colour so if you're unsure look for a row of extra pins or “contacts" on what's called the “substrate” (it's the little coloured bit).
